utterances: But there's already plenty of chaos and confusion.
In the last few weeks, Pakistan has been hit with one suicide bombing after another, many of them successfully targeting the security forces.
There's a new insurgency led by a cleric demanding Sharia law in the Swat Valley in northwest Pakistan, once a tourist haven.
The army seems to be making little impact.
In the tribal bout, several hundred Pakistani soldiers have been held hostage for weeks after surrendering to pro-Taliban militants, evidence of a general collapse in morale.
However, today's decision probably has more to do with Pakistan's Chief Justice Iftikhar Chaudhry.
The current political crisis in Pakistan began in March when Musharraf tried to sack him.
Chaudhry refused to work and began to tour the country in a convoy, sometimes attracting huge crowds.
Pakistan's legal community led the way.

The Khmers took power in 1975 when Sethisak was five and ruled for four years.
Money, education and all freedoms were abolished.
That meant most music, too.
But Sethisak remembers being fascinated by sound so he built his own kind of music.
I did a kite, right, a kite with a sound inside.
When you fly it, it sound on the top.
It's like flying, floating sound, you know.
And I fly it at nighttime, I hear the sound and I love it.
After the Khmer Rouge, Sethisak's father, a trumpeter and music theorist, became the director of Phnom Penh's fine arts school.
Sethisak studied piano and composition there and eventually won a scholarship to Russia.
Study in the Tchaikovsky College of Music in Moscow.
I lived beside the opera house in Russia and they took Kremlin, you know, like the Red Square.
And like from early in the morning, you'll hear music until late at night.
Music, music, music.
In the beginning, he sang like this.
(Singing in foreign language)
And then gradually…
(Singing in foreign language)
But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, most music scholarships were cut.
Sethisak's tuition and rent were still paid for, but he had to cover his other expenses.
Some of the sacrifices were tough.
If you survive in poor, poor time, why can't I survive in Russia?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I mean, in poor, poor time nothing to eat, at least, in Russia, have potatoes.
Three times a day, potatoes, you know.
Baking, you know, boiling, you know, mashed.
So I hate potatoes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
He returned to Cambodia after eight years in Russia.
Then he studied in Berkeley, California, but after the 9/11 attacks, he couldn't get his visa renewed.
I realize I review my life over there in Cambodia is war.
And over there, I never forget, I go to State, war again.
(Soundbite of laughter)
For a while he studied with Carlo Bergonzi, the world-famous tenor in Italy, but it costs thousands of dollars a month and he couldn't afford to stay long.
I don't get permanent, you know, training like other singers because of lack of funding.
So I practice, like, afternoon.
Always practicing my voice.
So trying to train, you know, myself, because I still have a dream to sing in the opera stage.
Singing ""Othello"" would be a dream come true, he says, but so with starting his own national opera school in Cambodia - if he can find funding.
I want the new generation, you know, like, to have more opportunity to reach out, you know, outside world, you know, so that I can teach more student and follow my dream at the same time.
Sethisak's performed all over Europe and in the States, but unless he puts on his own concerts, which he sometimes does, there isn't much opportunity in Cambodia.
There is the annual Fourth of July party at the American Embassy where he performs the national anthem for a little money on the side.
(Soundbite of song ""The Star Spangled Banner"")
(Singing) O say, can you see, by the dawn's…
Still, he practices twice a day inside his tiled bedroom where a piano is crammed in one corner and a mattress sits upright against the wall.
Daily training gives him focus, hope for the future, but it also means something larger and less well defined.
I'm a Buddhist, you know, so it's like a meditation, like you're trying to find yourself.
It's like you're trying to find your voice.
It's the same.
It's like endless discovering.
For NPR News, I'm Rachel Louise Snyder in Cambodia.

In July, Chaudhry was reinstated by Pakistan's Supreme Court.
He returned to the bench to lead a court that was, to the delight of many Pakistanis, willing to confront the military government.
The court decided to allow the recent presidential elections to proceed before it could decide whether it was actually legal for Musharraf to stand again.
